SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gwydir started off by saying some nice things about trade and how we are working together. Of course we are; we have to because Australia is at stake. He then said that we have failed to reduce inflation. What he and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) particularly fail to take into account is that because we have had a great devaluation, because the world does not want to pay us what is used to pay for our wheat-nearly $1 billion less-because the world does not want to pay us what we should be getting for our coal, this will have an effect on the rate of inflation. This morning I was engaged in discussions on coal as Acting Minister for Trade. We have had a devaluation of between 30 and 37 per cent. That has meant that the prices of goods that we import have gone up. Most of the inflation is coming from the imports. That is the problem.

The honourable member talked about foreign debt. If we have a 30 to 37 per cent devaluation our debt goes up by 30 to 37 per cent. We cannot put aside what has happened in the external accounts from what is happening in the domestic economy. But again we get double talk and double think from Opposition members, as if these factors can be separated out, as they separate the family out as having nothing to do with wage and salary earners. As I said, these abstractions, these nonsenses, will be discussed ad infinitum during the current election campaign and we will see many amazing scenes in the weeks ahead.

An election was called last week. The spokesman for one of the species of the National Party-he is no longer the shadow Minister-proposed this discussion of a matter of public importance today, and we welcome it. But whom does he speak for? Take just the announcement of the election. The Queensland Premier was in Disneyland. Apparently he is trying to find another car that runs on water, or something like that. His wife, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, said on radio last week: `Joh never wanted to be Prime Minister'. The reporter talking to her-I heard it with my own ears, and they are pretty big-asked: `But what about these green-and-white ``Joh for PM'' stickers'? She replied: `Oh, Joh didn't have anything to do with that. He doesn't want that at all'. But then I saw that the Queensland Premier had returned and he was with his adviser, Mr Stone, the man who when Secretary to the Treasury used to tell me that flat tax was a nonsense. He was also with Mr Copeman. Mr Copeman had already said that he was going to try to talk him out of it. But it is on again.

Mr Elliott was in the Soviet Union. Mr McLachlan was awaiting the call and John Valder, Chairman of the Liberal Party, called both Mr Elliott and Mr McLachlan to get them on the team. No doubt he is doing this as a confidence building tactic for the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It is a rather nonsensical proposition. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) is now saying that we should get all the conservative parties, all the four species of Opposition parties, together again. The poor old honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh)-it does not matter whether it is a.m. or p.m.-does not know whether he has got his seat or not. What a travesty to envisage the Queensland Premier, who has split the coalition and who has enabled a situation to occur in which hard right Howard takes the opportunity to purge the wets out of the Liberal Party, and I guess we can expect a policy speech soon from Macphee, Hall and Peacock, their clique--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will refer to honourable members by their electorates or by their titles.

—I understand, Mr Deputy Speaker. The National Party too is split. The reason why an outsider with a lot of hype from the New Right can split the two major parties in this House is that there is no consistency and no continuity of policy. There has not been for a long time. Opposition members go for anything. The Queensland Premier stands for flat tax. The Liberals want a broad-based consumption tax. SPEECH.PARA: It is possible to get the taxation statistics by post code area and I had a look at my electorate. The average resident in Werriwa would pay $400 more a year tax with a flat tax and the average person living in the north shore suburbs, such as Turramurra and places like that, would get $1,100 more. Who, on the Opposition benches, will decide agricultural policy? There is a Joh Nat running in Hume against the Liberal spokesman. The Queensland Premier has castigated the honour- able member for Gwydir, who normally talks a fair amount of sense. The Leader of the National Party-the one who sits in this place-the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is a hollow shell. I do not know for whom he is speaking up. I do not know what portfolio he thinks he has. He does not even say much these days, he is so destroyed. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) is not so happy now. He at one stage was the Queensland Premier's staunchest ally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still am.

—That is not what he is saying half the time. Sometimes he is for him, sometimes he is agin him. The honourable member for Maranoa simply does not know where he is. There could be at least four spokespersons for agriculture on the Opposition benches and the Queensland Premier is running a candidate against the Liberal spokesman for agriculture. SPEECH.PARA: The Government inherited a massively overvalued currency. That was the tactic of Mr Fraser. He had his big wages blowout-the de- regulation of wages-and brought down a wages freeze but to bring down inflation he overvalued the currency. Combined with this lack of wages policy was an 11 per cent inflation rate. This was ripping the guts out of all Australian industry, whether it was agriculture, mining or manufacturing. We have since been hit with an international agricultural trade war and falling commodity prices generally. That is why Australia has a balance of payments problem with the resulting accumulation of foreign debt. The Hawke Labor Government is fixing these problems and it will take time to wash the inflation out of the system.

We will have a look at interest rates. Every week I get from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics movements in the bank rates. The 90-day bank bill rate was 13.95 per cent on 21 May and that is the lowest for two years. The 10-year Commonwealth bond yield was 12.64 per cent on 21 May and that again is the lowest it has been for a considerable time-I am not quite sure whether it is two years. The rates are coming down. As we all know, housing rates are sticking but overdraft rates are coming down, with some prime rates at 16.5 per cent, so we are heading in the right direction.

We floated the currency, something no other government was ever prepared to do. We have accepted the discipline of a floating currency, a discipline the Opposition was never prepared to accept. As a result of the float, Australian industry is at record competitiveness. If the Opposition had its way and dragged the wage earners back to $171.30-the New Right wage-even that would not guarantee that we would sell another tonne of wheat when the United States of America is prepared to subsidise up to $44 a tonne at a time when no one else is in a position to supply-I am referring to the Soviet market.

Wages and competitiveness are not the problem; the problem is the corruption of trade and the stock overhang in the world markets due to subsidisation as a result of domestic policies and farmer pressures in the countries with which we compete. This means that, as a result of the currency float, Australia's cost structure is lower than it has ever been when compared to other countries' ruling exchange rates. This is turning the balance of payments problems around. It has cushioned grain growers from the collapse in world grain prices and facilitated the strong rise in wool prices we are currently witnessing. Not all industries are in as much trouble as the wheat industry; the so-called rural crisis is really a grain crisis. Cotton has picked up, sugar has evened out, beef is holding, there is a strong rise in wool prices and the devaluation of the dollar has given a breather to our horticultural and dairy industries. Rice is worst affected and then wheat, barley, oats and, of course, grain.

The process I have outlined has consequences, the first being, as I have said, an inevitable increase in the prices of imports. Even the Opposition should be capable of understanding the arithmetic that when imports account for 20 per cent of total supply in our economy and there is a 30 per cent currency depreciation, there will be a direct price effect of 6 percentage points. In other words, the current inflation rate of 9.4 per cent would be of the order of 3.4 per cent if the devaluation had not occurred. In the Government's first two years in office before the depreciation took effect, the Government got inflation down. It has gone up again-and even then not to the level the Opposition left behind-only because of the depreciation.

At the same time, most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries have benefited from low commodity prices and hence have been able temporarily to reduce their inflation rates. In other words, our bad luck is their good luck. They are using a new form of imperialism to hit those countries that have only basic commodities to produce because the legacy we inherited from governments that paid no attention to getting a balanced economy has left us in that vulnerable situation. As the currency stabilises-and there has been little movement against the trade weighted index since October-the currency effect on our inflation rate is washing out. That is why inflation slowed significantly in the March quarter and why it will slow further next year.

The second consequence is that, until the balance of payments turns around, the external deficit must be financed. This means we have had to pay higher interest rates than is the case overseas until the currency stabilises. Now that the dollar has clearly stabilised, interest rates are coming down. The most sensitive rates, such as the 90-day bill rate I have already mentioned, are at their lowest level for two years. The prime business rates have already started to follow. But what would the Opposition do? It is hard to say because, as I have already said, there are four Opposition parties in this House. Will the Bjelke-Petersen Nationals support the policies of the Sinclair Nationals? How can anyone believe any- thing the totally divided and confused National Party has to say? The same applies to the Liberal Party. Not one Liberal has voiced any support for the bright idea of the honourable member for Gwydir of replacing fuel taxes with consumption taxes. The Howard Liberals want a consumption tax to replace taxes on the wealthy.

Where do the Peacock Liberals stand? I read in this morning's Press that they had the numbers in the Liberal Party-37 to 36. Those 37 members have been gathered without one word of policy position being breathed to the public. Again, the leadership of the Leader of the Opposition is under threat. What a terrible indictment of the Liberal Party going into an election campaign in that mess due to this madman from the north who has split the coalition. The Deputy Leader of the National Party has made it clear that he wants a consumption tax. The Opposition likes to criticise every single indirect tax measure of this Government but then wants to go much further and implement a full scale consumption tax. Such a tax would push inflation right through the roof.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a fascinating performance by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). He must be terrified of Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen. He spent half his speech denigrating him and running him down. In the last 15 minutes the Minister has been whistling in the cemetery. Most certainly this election will be about the Hawke socialist Government's mismanagement of the economy. An integral part of that folly is the tragedy of high inflation and fearsome interest rates. The Government will be reminded time and again during the election campaign about that folly. That is its indelible legacy. It is all very well for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industry to profess innocence, to wash their hands of the matter and to pontificate that interest rates must be set by the market without government interference, but the Government must accept the blame and the odium for the calamity we have in this country where home owners are having their homes repossessed, where family farms are being sold, and where small businesses are collapsing.

SPEECH.PARA: In this very Parliament, not once but frequently, we have heard the Prime Minister proclaiming that interest rates and inflation would fall. We have heard the Treasurer boasting that his management of the economy is so sound that interest rates and inflation would fall. Those measures have fallen flat on their face. That is the only fall. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has been singing the same song. I will talk about the Minister for Primary Industry in a moment. The reality is that there has been no fall in interest rates and that interest rates in Australia by any comparison are disastrously high. Families acting on those bogus assurances have been betrayed and destroyed. The Minister for Housing and Construction in this House today made all sorts of statements, but the fact is that families which have contracted home loans in recent months are facing interest rates of 15 1/2 per cent, 16 1/2 per cent or even higher. Farm loan interest rates in many cases are much higher than those rates.

I have on the Notice Paper a question asking the Minister for Housing and Construction not about the number of housing starts but about the number of repossessions. The same question can be asked about the farming community. In my electorate office-and I guess in the electorate offices of many honourable members-are being seen more and more families who are losing their homes or losing their farms because of one factor-the high interest rates that are putting repayments beyond their reach. It is all very well to advertise home savings grants, as was done here today in this House, to provide a deposit, but very few seem to qualify and those who do are very often unable to cope with the escalating repayments. All the Minister is doing is coaxing young couples into contracts that they cannot possibly manage because of the Government's legacy of high inflation and high interest rates.

That is tragedy enough but let us look at the rural sector, where the scenario is even more disastrous. How does this Government project itself as competent in managing the economy when farms are being foreclosed, machinery is being repossessed and sold, and third and fourth generation farmers are ending up with nothing to sustain them and their families? That certainly boggles the mind. Of what value are the promises and assurances of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industry when the reality is so very much different? This Government, which has been the lackey of the trade union movement, has surpassed all other governments in their imposition of taxation. Yet despite this great harvest, its massively increased overspending has seen huge deficits and unsurpassed increases in the national debt. Of course, this has forced interest rates through the ceiling. That is the Government's fault. Interest rates have been kept high because of deliberate Government policy decisions. The harvest is tragic. A government which piously professes concern for the family has, by its own mismanagement, visited upon thousands of Australian families complete and unmitigated disaster. There has been a savage attack on and an indifference towards rural Australia. The specious alibi that the rest of the world is to blame, that commodity price falls are the cause, simply will not wash. The reality is that Australia's family farmers have been regarded as expendable and they have been betrayed. Not only is farm indebtedness increasing-and the predominant cause is not bad management but escalating interest rates-but also the capacity to survive is destroyed. Machinery is repossessed. Money borrowed to prepare the ground, to plant, cultivate and harvest the crops is subject to such prohibitive rates of interest that the proceeds are gone long before the harvest has even commenced.

Farmers are used to fluctuations in commodity prices. They have experienced them for years. They can contend with droughts and bad seasons because Australia's farmers are the best and the most efficient on earth, but they cannot continue to exist while we have a government which is so insensitive that it establishes the environment for inflation and interest rates beyond any that most of the farmers in competitive countries have to face. Australian family farmers can compete, they can fight, and they can win if this Government does not tie their hands behind their backs. Tragically, this union-dominated Government neither cares nor understands. It even stands back and does nothing when the crops end up on the wharves and unions refuse to load them for export. That is the heart, or lack of heart, this Government has. There is no other conclusion to which anyone can come except that this Government is completely anti-rural, anti-farmer, and anti-family.

How many times in this Parliament have we heard Australian Labor Party members pronouncing farmers as privileged, affluent, and even tax cheats? Honourable members cannot deny it. Every incentive and every assistance provided to help family farmers to survive has been attacked. Rural reconstruction has been slashed. Tax concessions have been annihilated, and capital gains and fringe benefits taxes have been levied without any mercy at all. No sector of the Australian community has had to bear so much. Interest rates have often delivered the coup de grace. Costs rise as inflation goes up unchecked. Our rate of inflation, which this Government promised would fall, is as much as four times higher than that of our competitors.

How any government can claim that we have turned the corner when Australian family farmers are being destroyed by a combination of high inflation and high interest rates is incomprehensible. What corner have we turned? We have turned the corner and we are running madly downhill. Farmers are being destroyed. The blame must be laid at the door of this Government. Inflation will be unchecked and it will increase further while the massive spending and the deficits continue to proliferate. Pressures upwards on interest rates cannot be assuaged while we have to borrow to finance this prodigality. Even worse, we are not borrowing to increase our competitiveness or to strengthen our economic base; we are borrowing to finance Medicare, our social security scheme and our unemployment benefits-in other words, to finance our housekeeping expenses. What a saga of irresponsibility and mismanagement.

What does the Government do? It makes another statement and it issues more promises. It brings in a Budget in August and by December it is obvious to all that the projected deficit will be considerably increased. It promises to make cuts and it erects a straw man of projected or forecast expenditure and then with great fanfare proceeds to knock it down. The May statement, which needed to reflect real cuts in expenditure of $4 billion to $5 billion, was a fiasco-a garage sale, if buyers can be found, shifting the cuts to State and local authorities, and deferrals of expenditure were indeed a sleight of hand; and the cuts, in reality, were a little over $1 billion. It will not even make a dent in inflation and interest rates. No wonder the Government has called an election before the Budget has to be produced.

The cost of the annihilation of family farms and small businesses will become even more horrendous as the year goes on. The chickens have come home to roost. There is not one Australian family which has not been grievously hurt by the legacy of inflation and crippling interest rates which are the hallmark of this shocking Government. The people and the farmers are not fools. There is no doubt at all what their verdict will be. This Hawke socialist Government, the architect of this mess, will be thrown out of office. All Australian farmers want is a chance to work and to survive. We will give them that help which has been spurned and denied by the worst Government this country has experienced in the whole of its history.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly agrees with the objective of reducing inflation and interest rates, which has been identified in this matter of public importance today. The Opposition, in its present multi-faceted divisions, has the problem that only the Hawke Government is capable of achieving these reductions. SPEECH.PARA: The National Party talks about the critical need to reduce inflation and interest rates, but let us not forget that for seven long years in coalition-as it then was with the Liberal Party-the National Party helped rather unmercifully to tear our agriculture industry to shreds. What was the then coalition's record? Inflation was 14 per cent in 1976-77, and in the seven years between 1976-77 and 1981-82 it was an average of 10.25 per cent. Who insisted on an overvalued Australian dollar in the Fraser-Howard years in the absence of a decent wages policy? None other than the then Treasury Secretary, and now Joh's economic adviser, one John Stone. What were the effects of this advice? The effects were very clear and included the destruction of the competitive position of Australian manufacturing, and the rural sector was held back from reaping the advantages of a relatively buoyant prices period in the early 1980s. Remember what happened to the National Party in the early 1970s when the Whitlam Government cut tariffs across the board by 25 per cent? What did the then Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony, have to say? He accused the then Government of cowardice. Between 1976 and 1983 there was no effective action against international protectionism by the then Treasurer the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is the current Leader of the Liberal Party.

The Government welcomes this matter of public importance debate. On the two issues identified by the National Party it is clear that what the Government will do, and has done, is much better than honourable members opposite could ever hope to do-and their record is a sorry testament to that. They stand condemned from their own mouth on the two issues selected for this debate this afternoon. What does that leave? It leaves the sort of paranoia reflected in the wording of the matter of public importance about enabling `primary industry and family farmers to survive'. The fact of the matter is that, if the previous Government's policies had continued-if we still had farm cost inflation at 11 per cent and if we still had an overvalued currency-farm incomes would have been completely wiped out some time ago. In this context it is interesting to point out that a one per cent change in farm costs brings about a return of some $130m to Australian farmers, and a one per cent change in currency brings about an additional $100m in farm receipts. So most thinking farmers can see for themselves the beneficial effects of the currency depreciation that has occurred under this Government-a government which has had the guts to take the big decisions, including floating the Australian dollar.

We all acknowledge that there are problems in Australian agriculture at present, but it is at least pleasing to see the honourable members opposite not using the term `rural crisis' as if to imply-as they have in the past-that there is some sort of broad brush problem in Australian agriculture at present. We know, as the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has indicated, and I am sure as the Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) is prepared to concede, that there are problems of low prices for grains and some other commodities as a result of the international agricultural trade war. However, these problems are by no means universal among Australian farmers. Of course, there is a great deal of diversity in Australian agriculture across commodities, across regions and certainly across individuals. Even among the grain growers of Australia, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates that less than 20 per cent are at risk of financial difficulty. By July 1987 there is an expectation that the average farm in Australia will be worth $624,600 and the average farm debt will be $74,000. That leaves average equity of 88 per cent in Australian farming. As I have indicated, 35 per cent have no debt at all. However, the highest 12 1/2 per cent of farmers-mainly those in the grains industry, who are having extraordinary difficulty at the moment because of the international trade wars-have debts of $163,500 on average. However, other industries are doing relatively well because of the policies of this Government.

We have seen wool prices at record levels and, as a result, no sheep farmers are considered at risk by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. While some farmers have very high debt loads, as the figures have indicated, and hence face some difficulties from the present high interest rates, the fact remains that the vast majority of farmers are in a very reasonable position as far as interest is concerned. It is not true that the future of the sector itself is at risk. We have this crisis mentality, this constant talk of crisis across the Australian agriculture sector from an Opposition which is just devoid of economic policies and policies in the agriculture scene that would do anything about it. The latest forecast from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, interestingly enough, is for a 30 per cent increase in farm incomes this year. That is certainly welcomed by this Government, which appreciates that there have been some difficulties, particularly with respect to Australian farm incomes, for some time. However, the sector will survive. It is a very resilient sector which will survive because the policies of this Government have given it a competitive position so that it will be able to survive. We recognise that there are individuals at risk-and that is why it is important that we have wound up the rural adjustment scheme to record levels. Most people concerned with the agriculture scene at present would recognise that the rural adjustment scheme is currently financing 10 times the proportion of total farm debt that was the case under the previous Government. However, we hear the Deputy Leader of the Sinclair faction of the National Party-and again this sentiment is echoed by his colleague from the Joh faction of the National Party who spoke earlier this afternoon-trying to suggest that this Government does not care for agriculture, that we have some sort of callous approach to people involved in the rural sector. I think actions speak louder than words. This Government has the runs on the board.

The Minister for Primary Industry has indicated, and most reasonable people would accept, that there are good reasons to explain the present quite high interest rates in Australia. Many honourable members would recall the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers in this House making the very valid comment that no government in its right mind would have some sort of masochistic approach to keeping interest rates at a continuing high level. That is not good economics, and it is certainly not good politics if one wants to look at it in that sense. So there is no masochism. We are taking policy initiatives in order to reduce interest rates, but it takes time to do that. Unfortunately, there is no acknowledgment from the other side of the House of the steps that we have taken. Only this Government has been able to do something about unwinding the rather pathetic legacy left to us by the previous Government. We have a firm fiscal policy that will reduce the 1987-88 prospective deficit by more than $4 billion to ensure that the task of winding back the $9.6 billion deficit that was left to us by the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in 1983 continues. So much for fiscal restraint when compared with some of the Mickey Mouse actions of the so-called Liberal Party razor gangs in the 1970s. Our wages policy is adjusted for inflation and is actually creating jobs. We have created over 780,000 new jobs since March 1983, in contrast with the sorry record of our predecessors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall commence my speech by referring to interest rates because they are relevant to the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill. The Bill has been introduced to change the timing of payments to local government from annual payments to quarterly payments. Previously, payments were made in a lump sum, usually in September. After the enactment of this legislation, the payments will be no later than 15 August, November, February and May, except for this year when the first quarterly payment will not be made until September. SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's attitude to the measure must be seen within the broader context. Prior to the May economic statement we called on the Federal Government to cut spending substantially. This Government has relied excessively on monetary policy to cover its policy mistakes. It has failed totally to provide and to produce an economic climate geared to providing incentive. Private capital investment has absolutely fallen through the floor under Labor. The industrial relations system is clogged, to say the least, thus preventing a flexible response to our balance of payments problem. The range of new anti-business taxes has been, again, another disaster heaped on business in this country. So much for the Government's claims that some aspects of these anti-business taxes were innocuous.

The estimates of the amount which the Government will collect from the fringe benefits tax have been revised upwards. The capital gains tax was the classic of all time. At the same time, inflation is ripping along at many times the rate of our international competitors. All this is happening whilst the clouds of international difficulties are gathering on the horizon. Given the vital national importance of moving away from monetary policy to a greater reliance on fiscal policy, the Opposition will not stand in the way of the Government's measures. However, let me say that we do so even though some of last year's measures and some of this year's measures are not measures that we would have introduced.

In general terms, the May economic statement has much in common with last year's Budget. Honourable members will remember that in May 1986 we had the spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) going off to see the pandas in China. Whilst he was there the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced to the country on a radio program that we were turning into a banana republic. The suggestion was that tough and hard decisions would have to be made. Before the Budget the Prime Minister returned to the theme and said that things were so crook we had war-like conditions and the Government would have to be very tough. In the 1986-87 Budget there were many one-off measures which certainly hurt. However, the bottom line was that expenditure was maintained in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want us to be a lot tougher, do you?

—This year, we were told again how tough the Government would be, with the Grim Reaper and so on. One could say that the $4 billion figure has had a decent ring about it. But as John Stone said on television last night, the whole thing is an absolute swindle. One billion dollars of that $4 billion comes from asset sales. No one really thinks that that is a cut. No one in his right mind believes that that $1,000m will be received into the Government's coffers in the 1987-88 financial year. There were some tax increases, which were par for the course for this Government. It is the biggest taxing government that we have ever had. The States received a cut of $1,000m. So the $4 billion is not so much a cut as a reduction in the 1987-88 Budget deficit from between $6 billion and $7 billion to between $2 billion and $3 billion. In other words, for all the talk about cutting government expenditure the Government's own figures show that next year we will spend $2 billion to $3 billion more than we will receive. One does not need to be an economist to know that if one continues to spend more money than is coming into the household budget, in the end, one starts to go down the drain. That is exactly what has been happening under this Government. Again last night Mr Stone, the former Secretary to the Treasury-he knows what he is talking about-made the point that next year there will be a marginal increase in real government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not stand in the way of the measures introduced to cut expenditure. But that is not to say that the measures will not have adverse consequences for local government. I must say, in response to the interjection by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) a minute ago, that one of the really frustrating things that local members find when talking to people is that, whilst the Government talks about cutting expenditure, it maintains a whole range of wasteful government enterprises and activities. We still have the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the Constitutional Commission and the Commission for the Future. How can the Government justify that when people--

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you rather have an Australia without a future?

—I can tell the honourable member that there is no future for a Labor government when there is such wasteful expenditure. What sort of a country is it when people come into my office and say `I need a hip replacement but I cannot have it done because there is insufficient funding of the health system' yet we see funds being provided for trade unionists and muralists and other wasteful expenditure. In Question Time today, the Government's expenditure on the National Media Liaison Service was revealed. An amount of $1.3m of taxpayers' money is going into a liaison service which is simply a propaganda unit for the Government. Apparently, the head of the Service is to work in Labor's campaign headquarters. Yet Labor members have the effrontery to come into this House and talk about cutting back expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: While the waste continues local government will feel the impact of this measure and it will add to the squeeze being put on local government through road funding cutbacks and the passing of the buck by State governments as their $1,000m cutback is fed through the system. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) is in the House. He is proud of his time in government. It would also be fair to say that one of the Socialist Left's interests in local government has been part of a wider plan to cut back the power of the States and to use local government and regional local government as a vehicle for centralised government.

Federal governments have provided many carrots for local government to go into new areas-and I know, because I have been in local government for a number of years-but after leading them up the garden path, with the carrot in front of them, they have then cut back on local government's recurrent funding. I can tell the Minister that people in local government have had enough of governments that undertake a policy of asking local government to take on the chores of the Federal government-and, in some cases, the State governments-and then not backing that with financial resources to allow it to do so.

Local government will have to adjust to a cut of up to $27m, either by reducing services in such areas as libraries, home help, kindergartens, infant welfare services and, in my electorate, beach cleaning, or it will be under pressure to increase rates. The Victorian shadow Minister for Local Government, Mr Robin Cooper, the member for Mornington-an excellent, newer member of the Victorian Parliament who has already made a great contribution-summed it up very well when he said:
Every ratepayer in the State will inevitably pay more and receive less in the way of services and road funds.
There is no doubt that that position will be reflected across Australia.

To obtain an indication of the impact on councils, I had some discussions, through my office, with the chief executive of the Shire of Flinders. It has a turnover in expenditure of about $35m; so it is quite a substantial council and, I might add, a very well run council. The financial impact of the measure we are debating will be in the vicinity of $55,000 to $65,000. That is not peanuts by any stretch of the imagination. Those cuts are in addition to the impact of a number of other measures. Road funding is not a subject that often reaches the front pages of the local newspapers or the daily Press, but it is one of the prime responsibilities of local government, and a very important one. This Government has already overseen massive cuts in real terms in road funding. Expressed in constant prices, in 1983-84 the figure was $1,359m; in 1986-87 it was $1,152m; and in the May economic statement there were cuts in the forward Estimates of $180.3m for 1987-88 and $192.5m for 1988-89.

All of that is in addition to the money that the Government pinched by way of the fuel excise. Honourable members will remember that a 2c levy was introduced by the Fraser Government on the Australian bicentennial road development program. It has been an excellent program, important for Australia's national infrastructure, and it has been funded by a levy of 2c a litre on fuel. The Government indexed that figure and it then snatched the indexed amount. On the latest figures, that amounts to $192m. There are roads in my electorate that have been part-made and no one can say when they will be finished because the Government has its hands in the till designated for funding important road projects.

The home and community care project has sustained a cut of $6.9m in the forward Estimates, yet it is an important area of local government. Local government will feel the impact of the increased taxes and charges on Telecom and Australia Post, especially the rural municipalities that have such a great reliance on the telephone and are disadvantaged by their locality. Local government will also feel the pinch from the cut in the community employment program. By and large, it has been responsible for and the major participant in that program. The cut for 1987-88 is $100m and for 1988-89 it is 200m.

The cuts generally come within a wider context, and I wish to make a few comments about that. Local government's share of public sector outlays has declined from 14 per cent in the early 1970s to about 6 per cent today. That has been accompanied by growth in both Federal and State Budgets and non-Budget sectors. The Government's contention that local government is a major contributor to growth in public sector deficits is not supported by the facts. In the early 1970s, local government was financing more than 15 per cent of its outlays from deficits or borrowings, but by the mid-1980s, only 4 per cent were being financed that way. It would be fair to say that, in effect, local government is shouldering a very considerable share-some might say an unfair share-of the burden of the Government's May mini-Budget, and this measure is part of that burden.

The Opposition does not oppose these measures as there is a vital need to cut Federal expenditures if there is to be any chance of cutting interest rates and arresting our economic problems. But let no one be in doubt that these cuts will hurt local government, which will feel continuing concern as this Government adds to uncertainty about its financing arrangements. It was this Government that cut the 2 per cent base measure that the Fraser Government gave local government as a basis for certainty in its financing. In this measure today, there is yet another example of Australian families having to feel the fall in living standards either through fewer services from local government or increased taxes.
I look forward to the election on 11 July. It will give Australians the opportunity to cast their verdict on this Government for its high taxes, falling living standards and economic mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill has only one purpose-to introduce a system of quarterly instalments for the payment of the Commonwealth general purpose assistance to local government. Previously, the payments were made annually, but in line with most other Commonwealth payments they will now be made quarterly. It is a reasonable amendment to procedures. The Commonwealth receives revenue continuously throughout the year, so there is no reason why payments should be made in one annual lump. Quarterly instalments will allow the timing of receipts and payments to be more closely matched.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a short Bill, and I have only a few remarks to make. It is, however, a useful opportunity to reflect briefly on some of the Government's achievements and to make a couple of general remarks about local government. There has been a 50 per cent increase in local government funding during the four years since the last year of the Fraser Government. The Federal Government is investing substantially in the development of local government because of the cost effectiveness of local government expenditure. Local government receives about a quarter of its total revenue from grants provided by the Commonwealth and the States. Commonwealth outlays on local government now exceed $1 billion, relative to total net outlays of local government on ordinary services of $4 billion. In 1986-87, the Commonwealth is providing for local government about $590m in untied grants, $220m for roads, another $130m for community services, about $90m for employment projects and about $35m for special projects. All those special allocations are clearly in high priority areas, and should be strongly supported because they are very much desired by the community.

The House will be aware of the revised arrangements for the allocation of untied grants among councils. The Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986, which the Bill we are debating amends, provided for continuity in the provision of funds, including real terms maintenance guarantee for both this year and next year; that is, total funds provided by the Commonwealth under this allocation will be maintained in real terms in both this year and next year. That Act also requires a more open and accountable system for the allocation of funds and for a gradual direction of funds to the most disadvantaged councils. The Department of Local Government and Administrative Services is currently consulting on the new principles to be adopted by State grants commissions. In some States these are close to being settled. Local government has been, or will be, consulted in each State about proposed changes, and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) will consult with the Australian Council of Local Government Associations before finalising the Commonwealth's response.

The Government, of course, would have liked to do more. I know that the Minister would have liked to do much more. But Australia is in the midst of a serious contradiction in the value of our exports. Everyone in the community should now know that the terms of trade have declined dramatically. A clear example of that is that the price of a tonne of wheat three years ago was $154. Now, all we can get for a tonne of wheat is $100. With a decline in the value of our exports as severe as that, there has inevitably been an increase in our current account deficit. Our current account deficit last year was about 6 per cent of gross domestic product; that is, 6 per cent of our national income. That means that in order to stop growth in our overseas debt, we must both reduce imports and increase the value of our exports. The May statement, which was criticised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), was designed centrally to reduce outlays so as to reduce the total level of our imports.

I was amazed by the previous speaker's comments because he appeared to be saying that these cuts were in some way irresponsible. I would have expected him to accept that they were responsible, that they were an absolutely necessary element of an appropriate strategy to reduce imports. The cuts not only were important overall, but also they were designed in such a way as to minimise the cost that they caused the community. They were concentrated in areas in which they would most effectively reduce imports. Cuts in areas which would contribute to increasing exports were minimised. For example, there was a cut in defence spending, but other areas of investment which are absolutely essential to build up our export base and our national productivity were either not touched or were cut only to a very small extent.

The point about the Opposition is that it has a doctrinaire approach to slashing public expenditure. It simply wants to lash into the public sector so that it can increase the after-tax incomes of the wealthy. It talks about reducing taxes for the already well off, the already wealthy and high income earners, which is both an inequitable and an irresponsible policy. It is really guided by a doctrinaire approach to the economy which in some way sees the public sector as being less effective than the private sector, whereas the reality throughout Australian history has been that we have had effective public-private sector co-operation. Private sector investment grows fastest when public sector investment is also growing rapidly. In other words, the Opposition is closing its mind and its eyes to the empirical realities. It is not noticing what has happened in Australia during the last two centuries. It is simply proposing destructive policies which would have the effect not only of slashing essential services for the whole community but of stopping economic growth throughout the community. Such an approach is utterly irresponsible.

It is important that the strategy of the May statement be continued. We must build up our national investment in both the public and the private sectors so that we can build up our exports and our national productivity. That is the way that we will restore balance to the external account. I am at present involved in chairing an inquiry into the national infrastructure by a sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. An excellent submission to that inquiry was made by the Australian Council of Local Government Associations which entirely accepted this approach. It advocated the need for investment in roads and other important services in rural and urban areas. That recommendation, which it argued most cogently, will, I am sure, be accepted by all members of that Committee.

I make just two other brief comments. I represent half of the Australian Capital Territory. In the Australian Capital Territory we do not have local government. We are the only part of any Western country which has no local control over its own affairs. This means that Commonwealth Government preferences and priorities are imposed on the Australian Capital Territory. Of course, the Commonwealth Government throughout the history of Canberra has been benevolent and relatively sensitive to community opinion in the Australian Capital Territory. Nevertheless, it is unsatisfactory that local government functions and most State government functions are not under the control of people elected by the people of the Australian Capital Territory. It seems to me very important that as soon as possible regional responsible government be introduced in the Australian Capital Territory. The Government tried to do that during the term of the present Parliament, but was stopped by opportunism and rigidity in the Senate. However, I am very hopeful that when Labor is re-elected at the next election another attempt will be made to get that very sound proposal for responsible regional government in the Australian Capital Territory through Parliament. That is essential not only to ensure that the preferences of the local community are reflected in local policy but also to ensure that the principles of democratic responsible government, which are so important and are embodied in Commonwealth, State and local government in every other part of Australia, are embodied in government in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Minister mentioned in his second reading speech that it was likely to be his final speech in this House as Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. I conclude by praising the Minister's strong commitment to local government in Australia. He has certainly struggled wholeheartedly and with strong commitment for local government in Australia. He has recognised the importance of accountable local governments in the best tradition of participatory democratic institutions. Contrary to what the previous speaker had to say, the Minister has always supported decentralisation and devolution of powers. That has been very much part of both his philosophical and his practical policy orientation. I congratulate the Minister on his fine achievements and on the length and strength of his struggle for effective local government in Australia, which goes back to the early 1970s, of course, as he was Minister for Urban and Regional Development in the Whitlam Government. He has been responsible for much pioneering work in the area of both local and regional government. He has made a fine contribution to equitable development in Australia, and I think it is important to recognise that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill that is presently before the House-the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987-amends the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986 and will have effect from 1987-88. It will implement a quarterly system of instalments to be paid to local government. The instalments will be paid on 15 August, November, February and May respectively. However, due to the late presentation of the legislation, the first quarterly payment due on 15 August will not be paid on time and will occur around the same time as the previous annual payment, which has hitherto been before the end of September. From the 1988-89 financial year, local government will receive its first quarterly instalment approximately four weeks earlier than had previously been the case. The changes will not affect the amount being provided to local government under the Act nominally, but there will be a loss in revenue principally as a result of interest revenue forgone. The legislation is introduced to enable the Commonwealth to better match outlays and receipts, resulting in a saving in public debt interest payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past decade local government authorities have received Federal government financial assistance on an annual allocation basis calculated at 31 August and paid in a lump sum during September. Local authority budgeting is geared to receipt of that money at that time. Spending programs by local government are, therefore, geared to this budgetary system. Naturally, all moneys are not spent immediately, thus allowing local authorities to invest the balance of funds available and earn interest on such investments. The Federal Government has estimated that the cost of the present method of annual lump sum payments will be $27m in the forthcoming financial year by way of interest on its overseas borrowings. The introduction of a system of quarterly payments to local government is linked to decisions made at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings on 25 May 1987 to cut back the Commonwealth's general purpose payments to the States. Of course, local authorities will suffer some financing problems this year due to the late implementation of the changes and may have to resort to borrowings through banking institutions to tide them over the change.

At first blush it would appear morally proper of the Commonwealth Government to withdraw, if one likes, the potential of local authorities to earn an amount in the vicinity of $27m, based on the simple proposition: Why should not the taxpayers, through the Commonwealth Government, have the benefit of that facility rather than local government authorities? But, of course, the reality of the matter is that the Commonwealth has been fully aware of the interest earning capacity of local government through this annual funding and has therefore recognised it as part and parcel of moneys essential for the proper operation of local government. In short, local government is suffering a loss of $27m, though not necessarily sustainable in precise terms because, while the Commonwealth, naturally from a superior position, has the ability to best exploit the market-place in terms of interest offering and various machinations, local government may not necessarily be equally as well equipped. In fact we do not know just how the local authorities within Australia have arranged the investment or placing of the September payments hitherto to supplement their direct grants.

The situation now is that the Commonwealth has elected to adopt a course of action; a benefit accrues to the Commonwealth and a disadvantage applies to the local government authorities. It is commendable that the local government authorities, in common with the States, have by and large responded to the Commonwealth Government's appeal-indeed, demand-that we exercise some financial restraint. But it is also food for thought that this notional across the board reduction of grants and available moneys does not necessarily pay any respect whatsoever to relative worth. Over the years there has been a drift in areas of government funding and community activity which establishes a disparity. Ideally, when restraint has to be applied across the board, we should in the first instance bring everybody up to par. The local government authorities are quite insistent that they have acted responsibly over the years. My colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who preceded me in this debate, drew the attention of the House to the fact that the proportion of borrowings by local authorities to sustain their operations has reduced over the years from 15 per cent to 4 per cent, which is quite a commendable effort, whereas on the other hand, the Commonwealth has gone in the opposite direction.

It is fair comment that, in this notional saving of $4,000m announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May statement, the Commonwealth has fallen far short of bearing what may fairly be argued to be its responsible share of financial restraint. When it comes to it, that $4,000m is less the $1,000m restraint imposed upon the States, less the $1,000m raised by selling off the farm-with which I have no particular argument if our circumstances are so urgent that it must be done to maintain our solvency-and less the $400m extracted from statutory authorities, which leaves a fairly humble $1,600m for the Commonwealth to hold forth as clear proof that it has demonstrated the same responsibility as local government has over the years.

I know that the retiring Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren), who is presently absent from the House, has taken great pride in his contribution over the years to the well-being of local government. I know that he must have been taken aback slightly by the suddenness of the imposition of this measure. I noted that in his statement to the House in respect of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance he made the observation that he shared the concerns expressed by both the States and local government that any changes to be implemented should be gradual and not unduly disruptive to individual councils and the local government system generally. I think that comment could relate to this measure which is utterly deficient in meeting that criterion. That is probably the greatest fear of local government because it is not in a position yet to accurately measure the extent of this imposition.

Within Australia, there are different financial year arrangements. I understand that New South Wales operates on a calendar year and that other States operate on a financial year. Of course, New South Wales will be in the position of expecting a 12-monthly lump sum payment in September and will have programmed and budgeted accordingly. It will find now that it will receive only 25 per cent of that amount. No doubt it will adopt measures to overcome that impediment, but presumably that will put it on to the loan market, which is totally in conflict with the philosophical and practical thrust of what the Government has been about lately, as emphasised to the Premiers at the Premiers Conference when they were told that the deficiencies that they will suffer should not be made good by going to the loan market, which would increase our indebtedness, to accommodate that short term requirement. The States were told that they should not seek to sustain the position that they have hitherto enjoyed and that in reality they have to accept a belt-tightening exercise.

I guess it could be said that the local government authorities may even be relieved that they escaped some of the rigours that they perhaps feared in prospect and may feel that things are not as bad as they could have been. But presently they have great trouble in putting a dollar value on the effect of this new arrangement, it being so close to the time when local authorities would normally expect the first quarter to be paid. I am sure they will be comforted to know that the Bill will stipulate when the payments will be made, particularly in this transitional first year.

I am mindful that there are some time constraints on debate. The Bill will not invite opposition from this side of the House, for the simple reason that it is a budgetary measure and is well within the entitlement of the Government that it pass both Houses so that the Government can maintain its budgetary commitment to the States. But we should not forget that the 838 local authorities in this country are served by in excess of 9,000 or 10,000 aldermen and councillors-volunteers in the main-who render a great service to this country. In much of this country, in the non-metropolitan and rural areas in particular, it could be said that local government is virtually the life blood of the community. If it were to suffer adverse circumstances to the effect that it could no longer maintain its position in the community, there would be a disastrous flow-on to the community.

It is worth bearing in mind also that the proposal that local government activities could be relegated-I use that word advisedly-to a substantial extent to private contracting, while having some appeal, loses sight entirely of the critical role of local government authorities in rural areas. They serve an emergency role in floods, in tragedy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fire.

—And fire. They are on the spot immediately to move in and contend with whatever has to be dealt with, whereas, if we had to rely entirely on private contractors, they could be 1,000 miles away. So we have to maintain them. They are a very important element within our national infrastructure. Whilst this Bill does not savage them to the extent that it could, it will have an effect on them. I applaud their responsibility, their general attitude to respond to the requirement that we must exercise some restraint at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Without wishing particularly to introduce a discordant note, it is a sad fact that the situation we are presently in is aggravated by the tardiness of this Government and the preceding Government to get to grips with the problems which were emerging quite clearly in our country and which led to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) making a statement, unhappily only three months after claiming that ours was the most buoyant economy in the world, that our country was in fact facing a war for economic survival. I agree with him totally, and we should marshal our forces as best we can to deal with the main problems first, and we can fix up everything after we have won the war.

The Opposition parties-and I can see some of their members sitting in this House now smiling; they are like vultures ready to attack my innocent constituents-because of their attitudes to public sector spending, would ensure that Canberra was sucked dry if, unfortunately, they ever became the government of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Services dismembered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst noting that the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) indicated in the second reading speech that this might be the last Bill that he would bring before this Parliament, and accepting as I do that the Minister enjoys a fair degree of affection in this chamber, I have to say in passing that I am appalled that once again the Hawke socialist Government has betrayed a firm and fundamental commitment to local government. SPEECH.PARA: Even more confusing is the contradiction between the second reading speech by the Minister and the explanatory memorandum. The Treasurer has estimated that the Commonwealth will save $27m-
I repeat, $27m-
from changing from a single annual payment to a system of quarterly instalments.

My personal feeling is that it will probably come up to around $35m-ripped off, blatant misappropriation. TALK.START.PARA: —It is a betrayal.

What will the Opposition policies do for the Bega Valley Shire? They will reduce its income and force it into further inequitable rating increases and place further burdens on local ratepayers. The leadership is unable to bring the members together and the people will not vote for them.

The Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1987 and the Excise Tariff Validation Bill 1987 give effect to the Government's announcements on tariffs and bounties in recent times. The three principal areas of the Customs Tariff Validation Bill arise from, first, the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on vegetables and vegetable products; secondly, the Government's decision on the IAC report on luggage, handbags and similar containers; and, thirdly, consideration by the Australian and New Zealand governments on the duty free status of gas barbecues. There is a recommendation that gas barbecues be allowed into this country duty free. I point out that the Opposition does not oppose that.

SPEECH.PARA: The new tariffs will have some impact on the baggage and luggage industry but in the overall economic sense the Opposition feels that the proposal in this area should not be opposed. However, the Opposition finds the decision with respect to vegetables to be fairly extraordinary. We all know that the Minister's recommendation was for a tariff level of 15 per cent, but he was rolled because of the continuing anti-rural stance taken by the Government. The recommendation by the experts in Cabinet was to go down to 10 per cent. As a consequence, the frozen vegetable area and the large area of vegetable production in Australia will come under enormous pressure. It is worth looking at what goes on in the vegetable growing areas of rural Australia. Taken as a whole, the vegetable industry is the second or third largest crop enterprise and the fifth or sixth largest in the agricultural industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot comes from Bowen in my area.

—A lot comes from the Bowen area, including Bowen tomatoes. As the honourable member for Dawson knows, tomatoes will be affected significantly by the recommendations. The well known area of Bowen, which includes the Don delta, and the people of this area will be impacted upon. Their profitability will be shot to ribbons in the coming seasons because of this measure.
—They could be growing pretty big, too.

—If they are, I am sure that they will have a healthy glow on them. Vegetables have a particular significance, in some States more than others. Tasmania in particular has over 40 per cent of Australia's total crop value in vegetables; and for a State of that size to rely on one particular area is significant. In other States such as Queensland and Victoria the value of vegetables as a crop is in the order of 10 per cent. However, Victoria, for example, produces 27 per cent of all vegetables grown in Australia, followed by Queensland with 25 per cent, New South Wales with 18 per cent and the other States as a whole with 30 per cent. So if 40 per cent of Tasmania's total crop comes from vegetables, that is significant for that island State.

SPEECH.PARA: Domestic consumption accounts for 97 per cent by weight of all Australia's vegetable production. Therefore, at the moment only 3 per cent of our vegetables are exported. That accounts for the highly domestic consumption orientation in which this industry finds itself. Until fairly recently, the potato industry had been subject to a total import ban. When this was abolished recently we saw a fair penetration of the Australian market by foreign growers, particularly from New Zealand and more latterly from Canada. As a result, we have seen a buildup in the use of dehydrated potato and certain other manufactured potatoes coming into this country. They have been subject to substantial tariff protection until now. This validation Bill gives effect to the recommendation of the IAC report that the tariff level on these items be dropped to 10 per cent over a five-year period and that special monitoring take place. The Liberal Party and the National Party-the honourable member for Dawson will move an amendment in this regard at a later date-see this as an extreme measure which will be harmful to many areas of Australian potato production and we recommend that the tariff level be 15 per cent rather than 10 per cent. Australian producers would then be able to have some confidence in relation to future production.

There is a lot of talk about export markets. In this area the Japanese market was taken from Australian producers by the Unites States of America. There is a substantial export of vegetables into Europe, but it is very much on a one-off basis as a result of various crop failures due to climatic conditions. Everyone accepts and understands, although there may be some reservations about the appropriate level of petroleum and oil pricing in Australia at any particular time, the role of that import parity pricing system and the levy not only within the industry itself but also in terms of government revenue.

Of course, it was the Fraser Government that first introduced the levy on oil and turned every petrol bowser in Australian into an office of the Taxation Office. One of the great opportunities that the Fraser Government lost was to take that $3.5 billion raised from the levy and use it to reduce its deficit. Instead, it took the money and spent it. All of the fiscal problems associated with that action were inherited by the Hawke Government. It was one of the principal reasons why we inherited a deficit in prospect of $9.6 billion for 1983-84. A magnificent opportunity was lost by the Fraser Government to consolidate the fiscal position of the Commonwealth Government through the revenue flowing to it from that petrol levy. In the light of that Fraser Government attitude, the deficit for which it was responsible literally blew out during its last few years-in 1981-82 it was $500m; the following year, 1982-83, it had blown out to $4.5 billion; and we all know that, had the Fraser-Howard Government remained in office, the prospective deficit for the following year would have been $9.6 billion, representing about 5 per cent of gross domestic product.

As a result of fiscal discipline, fiscal restraint and fiscal responsibility, the Hawke Government has been able to haul back from the prospective deficit of about 5 per cent of GDP in its first year of office to less than one per cent for the 1987-88 Budget. That has been nothing short of a magnificent achievement by the Government. It is to the eternal discredit and shame of conservative parties in Australia that they took the $3.5 billion that came to them from the oil levy and used it, in effect, to buy votes. They used it not to haul back the deficit, but to finance recurrent expenditure. They did not even use it to finance capital expenditure.

There was no significant improvement in public investment in infrastructure from that windfall revenue for the Commonwealth Government. It was picked up and spent; and as a result the Australian nation found itself in serious fiscal difficulties, which the Hawke Government inherited. It is important that we keep that in mind. It was a wasted opportunity, a squandered opportunity and probably one of the worst examples of fiscal irresponsibility that any country has ever witnessed from any government at any time. SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Validation Bill arises from the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on luggage and vegetables and vegetable products, the granting of duty free entry to gas barbecues and barbecue parts from New Zealand and the variation in customs duty rates on imported petroleum products to align with changes in the excise duty on equivalent locally produced goods.

I want to deal with these separately. The luggage question has been mentioned. The Government has decided on a uniform general tariff rate of 15 per cent for most of the goods which were under reference. I want to spend time talking about vegetables and vegetable products because they are a very important part of this debate. The changes were introduced following the IAC final report on vegetables and vegetable products, delivered in April 1986. While some products will attain marginally higher tariffs, others such as certain potato products, flour, navy beans and tomato paste will find tariff rates substantially cut.

At the moment Italy exports a lot of tomato paste to Australia, and yet in our major tomato growing areas there is a lot of waste in supplying the fresh fruit market. An incentive should be given to Australian industry to compete against imports now the market has been established. The Australian industry could change into a major exporter, given some consideration and favour-which this cut in duty does not do. What I am saying is that our local industry should be encouraged, not discouraged, as is the case in this Bill.

Most other industries have average nominal and effective assistance of about 15 per cent, but the Government's package yields only between 3 and 10 per cent effective assistance for vegetables. The industry in Australia employs at least 10,000 people directly, with tens of thousands of indirect jobs also created. So it is a major employer in Australia. When talking about the threat of imports, the Australian producer fairly compares the cost of producing articles in Australia with the cost to overseas competitors. I mention interest rates as an example. It is known that interest rates in Europe are substantially lower than those imposed on Australian growers-sometimes one-quarter of the interest rates paid by Australian growers. West Germany, a country from which these frozen vegetables could come, has an inflation rate this year just marginally above zero, and Japan has an anticipated inflation rate below zero. These are major costs for Australian industry. It is easy to see how overseas producers can export canned vegetables to Australia at a lower cost than would be the case here. They do not have our input costs. They do not have a centralised wage system. They do not have the huge taxes and government imposts that we have in Australia. It is very important to make the point that if the Government is going to kick the crutch away from under the industry it has to do its part in bringing about economic stability and a lower cost regime so that our growers can compete.

The major supermarket buying groups or agents for supermarkets in Australia can give a very firm direction to the way that Australian consumers buy. I know of instances where superior Australian foodstuffs, which have to undergo the rigors of the health requirements and State requirements, are priced out of the market. Supermarkets go for the cheaper goods, those for which the manufacturers do not have to pay a price to put them on the supermarket shelves. I have heard of some manufacturers in Australia having to pay $10,000 just to find supermarket space for some lines. The goods that come from overseas are not faced with the same costs, and are much cheaper for the supermarkets. I want to stress that the imported goods do not have to meet the same health requirements as the Australian goods. One example is wine, although it is not included in this Bill. The State authorities make sure that the labels on Australian wine contain an exact description of the wine. But there is no State requirement for labels on imported wine to have that information. Other aspects of this Bill, such as those relating to gas barbecues, barbecue parts and petroleum products, have been mentioned. I want to talk in more detail about the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act, which provides for an export duty on high quality coking coal. It is being pressed very heavily on international markets. We have heard of severe decreases in the market price being forced on Australian producers, particularly by Japanese buyers. This accommodates a situation where coking coal, which normally brings a superior price on the world market, is now being forced to be sold as steaming coal, and this amendment is being made accordingly.

Other major difficulties-again they are imposed by the Government-keep the cost of coal up, in spite of the fact that the market in the outside world is falling. I want to relate my comments on the Customs Tariff Validation Bill to the situation which is pertinent to the northern part of Tasmania, and in particular to potatoes as a vegetable product. It is in the electorates of Bass and Braddon that the overwhelming majority of potatoes are produced. In fact, in my electorate of Braddon we have the largest potato factory. The industry is of great concern to the people on the north west coast of Tasmania. It is a very important industry. One factory alone processes 150,000 tonnes a year of fresh potatoes, and that does not take into account the growing of the seed potatoes in that area to produce the commercial crop. It is recognised by the Industries Assistance Commission that the regions of Devonport and Ulverstone will be most severely affected by these tariff proposals. I will therefore confine my comments to the effect on those people and that industry.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the real concerns which people in this industry have about the way in which the Government has gone about proposing a 10 per cent tariff is that so many different products come from potatoes which at present have quite a different range of tariffs. It seems to me and to many people that the Government is interested only in coming up with a single figure for all these different products. It does not realise that in industry different products need different competitive edges. Some products can be more easily sold in the market-place than others either without tariff restrictions or with them.

I will outline a few of the different vegetables which at the moment have a different tariff rating. For example the tariff on dehydrated potato at present is 50 per cent, and the Government wants to bring that down to 10 per cent. Yet the Government wants to increase the tariff on peas and beans from 2 per cent to 10 per cent. It is of concern to us that the goal of the Government is to introduce a tariff of 10 per cent instead of looking at each product carefully to see whether different products need different tariffs. As I said, different potato products have different tariffs.

The industry has spent hours and hours trying to get the Government to see its point of view on this issue. I was speaking to one of the members of the Australian Vegetable Industry Council only last week, who said that it seems as though they have spent all that time for nothing. The Government indicated that it would listen to the people involved but it went down an ideological track. It wanted to set a figure and it really did not matter how much representation there was or how much time had been put in by the people involved in this industry, whether at the processor level or at the grower level. Those people are concerned that the Government seems to be turning a deaf ear to any representation that they may make on these matters.

As I said, the north-west coast is an important area in Tasmania for producing vegetables. These farmers in recent years have suffered severely due to the differences between costs and prices. Consequently, any possibility of increasing tariffs and reducing competitiveness is to be looked at very carefully.
