TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about the cost pressure squeeze on rural people in northern Tasmania and in particular people in the horticultural industry growing potatoes and other vegetables. I shall continue on that line. These people are faced with the Industries Assistance Commission report which proposes to reduce tariffs on potatoes to around 10 per cent. The cost pressure squeeze on those people has included such things as interest rates, which have increased from 14 per cent to about 20 per cent for commercial loans for these people. There has been a devaluation of the dollar which has put up considerably the costs for people purchasing tractors and other machinery. Diesel prices have increased substantially. Petrol prices, we know, have gone from around 42c a litre since this Government was elected to about 64c a litre. Of course, there have been the inevitable increases in government charges.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the latest information we have, the average income in the horticultural industries in Australia will be around $3,900 per farmer and the real rate of return, including capital appreciation, is minus 13.5 per cent. So the industry is already struggling, already having great difficulty in making ends meet. The prices which rural people have received have not kept up with inflation over the last 10 years. The only way in which people in these industries have survived is by being much better managers, being more efficient and, in particular, increasing the productivity per hectare of their land. As the chairman of the vegetable growers in the northern part of Tasmania, Mr Max McKenna, said, it is ironic that the Government refused to protect the growers from potato imports but at the same time charged high tariffs on essential machinery. That really puts it in a nutshell. If the Government were prepared to reduce tariffs accordingly on the input side for the rural people in Australia I am sure farmers on the north-west coast of Tasmania would be prepared to look at accepting this reduction in tariffs. The burden has not been applied equally. The rural people of Australia are fully aware that people in other areas have been treated differently. Let us take the motor vehicle industry. People in that industry are subsidised by a tariff paid by taxpayers at the level of $16,000 per worker per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—I repeat, in reply to the honourable member for Wakefield, that it is $16,000 per year. It is a substantial amount. Yet the average income for farmers in the horticultural industry is only $3,900 a year. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics, in the IAC report, says that Tasmanian potato growers are virtually tied to the processing sector because they have fewer market alternatives than their mainland counterparts. So the processing industry in Tasmania is vital and it has ramifications throughout the community. A drop in the protection level to 10 per cent will mean that there will be competition from other parts of the world. McCain Foods (Australia) Pty Ltd said recently that it would build on the north-west of Tasmania a $15m potato processing plant but this is jeopardised and there is concern about whether it will go ahead with the project considering the reductions in tariffs. The rural producers know that McCain is a North American company and if potatoes can be produced in America at a cheaper price that will be used as a bargaining tool to keep down the price paid to growers in Australia. It is ridiculous that we cannot produce a product in Australia for domestic consumption.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry is prepared to accept a reduction in protection but the reduction to 10 per cent is far too great. It would be different if there were an across the board cut in tariff protection in all sectors of Australia but that simply is not the case. The Opposition has moved that protection be phased down to 15 per cent. I believe that is a reasonable level of tariff protection for this industry but to go lower than that will seriously jeopardise several communities in northern Tasmania. Over the last seven or eight years they have had to deal with the effects of the closer economic relations agreement with New Zealand and this reduction will put excessive pressures on the many families in this region. I ask the Government to give due consideration to the amendment which has been moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and trust that we can reach some reasonable compromise on this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1987, which relates to several different matters, but primarily to changes to section 226 of the Customs Act 1901 whereby the collection of duties in pursuance of any customs tariff proposal is protected against legal challenge for 12 months or until the close of the session of Parliament, whichever occurs first. With the calling of the election the introduction and passage of this Bill is a necessary machinery measure to protect the collection of the duties which have been introduced by the proposals. The proposals relate to collection of duties or variations of duties with regard to luggage, vegetables and vegetable products; granting of free entry into this country of gas barbecues from New Zealand; and the variations of the customs duty rates on imported petroleum products. The comments that I wish to make relate to what I believe is the most important of those items and that is the rates relating to vegetables and vegetable products.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this issue goes back to Industries Assistance Commission recommendations to the Government which this Bill puts into place. It has been going on for some considerable time-well over 12 months. The original draft report prepared by the IAC was done in January 1986 and the industry then had the opportunity to refer to it. The IAC looked at the potential for the development of the fresh vegetable and vegetable products industry in Australia and in particular identify and report on significant factors that may impede the growth of the industries or in other ways affect their competitiveness and efficiency. The vegetable industry is certainly growing and at a time when we need exports we all ought to be getting behind it. Taken as a whole, the vegetable industry is regarded as being second or third largest of the crop enterprises and fifth or sixth largest of the agricultural industries. The total value of vegetable production in 1984-85 was $551m, which is 4 per cent of total Australian agricultural production.

Vegetables are of major importance in my State of Tasmania and it is no coincidence that there are several Tasmanians speaking on this issue. Over 40 per cent of total Tasmanian crop value comes from vegetables whereas, for example, in States such as Victoria or Queensland the vegetable component is only 10 per cent. So one can see the very important role that vegetable growing plays in our State. Tasmania and Western Australia are major exporting States, too, with Tasmania supplying nearly 22 per cent of all vegetable exports, consisting mainly of onions. Potato exports represent in the vicinity of 6.6 per cent of total vegetables grown in Tasmania. They represent 35 per cent of all vegetable production-both fresh and processed. In my area we have a General Jones Pty Ltd factory, which is part of the Edgells concern, which is now producing frozen potato chips for export and for domestic use. There is certainly a great potential market available to it. The recommendation of the IAC report was to change the tariff protection from 50 per cent of the tariff on imported dehydrated potatoes and 20 per cent on processed frozen potatoes down to a single tier of tariff of 10 per cent on all imports.

It is interesting that, in seeking the views of industry, a unique body was set up, called the Australian Vegetable Industry Council, which was made up of growers, processors and unions. When one goes back to the Press release that was issued way back in June, one sees that the people who made up AVIC had great hopes of what it would be able to achieve. I quote from that Press release:

We are confident that such an initiative will promote a basis for stability in our industry, and for a meaningful industry development plan . . . We are now liaising with each sector of our diverse membership to ensure that the recommendations put to Government accurately reflect industry opinion.

Indeed, the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association also made comment, through Mr John Rich, its Executive Officer-an expert in potato growing, politics and the realities involved and also a man who has had vast experience with the difficulties in Tasmania with the dumping of peas in this country-who highlighted the grave dangers that would flow if there were a heavy reduction in protection. He made the point:
We already know what can happen to an industry when currency fluctuations make the Australian market temporarily attractive to import product.

That was certainly the case with peas. The Association signalled its deep concern about what could happen. What then happened, of course, was that AVIC, as it is called, prepared a draft report to the Government based on the IAC recommendations. The Council went into considerable detail. There is not time tonight to go into all the detail, but some of the issues raised were that a level of industry support consistent with that available to other manufacturing industries is what was being sought and that the industry is not a homogeneous one like some others that are available to be protected. The Council also made the comment that there would need to be assurance that the industry's base market is not disrupted by low priced and/or high volume imports of convenience from subsidised low cost sources and countries with unfettered access to the Australian market. Concern was also expressed about dumping. I shall comment about that a little later. The Council said about that:
. . . the imperative that the industry increase its volume and value of output, not only of existing products but by developing and retaining expanded markets, including exports.

Certainly, we could all feel some sympathy with that. We then get to the interesting political point of the whole exercise-that is, the recommendation that was made to the Cabinet. It is well known that the recommendation made to Cabinet by the two Ministers responsible-the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin)-was that changes in the tariff level should be at 15 per cent, which was recommended by AVIC, the all-industry body, after considering all the information that had been given to the IAC and also all of the discussions that took place within the industry. The two Ministers went to Cabinet and said: `That is what we want to do'. They were rejected and sent away and told that there had to be a 10 per cent, one tier, across the board reduction.

It is quite interesting to look at what went on. I have talked extensively with people from the Food Preservers Union of Australia who came to the Parliament to speak to honourable members who had an interest in this area-people from the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association, such as Mr John Richens, and many others. These people also talked with the Caucus industry committee and I understand that the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) and the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) gave them a very sympathetic hearing. Everyone on that committee was united, I believe, in supporting the Ministers taking their representations to Cabinet, yet they got knocked back and have walked away from the industry recommendation of 15 per cent.

If one has a look tonight to see who is on the speaking list, we do not see one Government member here to talk about, give voice to and express the concerns of the people whom they choose to represent. I think it is a dismal performance. They have just walked away from them again. Many people are out there working in potato factories. There are 6,500 people involved in the vegetable manufacturing industry. There are more than 6,500 growers around this country, and they have seen the Government turn its back on them. What the industry had to say about the new announcements when they were made is all summed up quite well in the response-and one has to remember that this body, the Australian Vegetable Industry Council, is made up of the growers, the unions whose members work in the factories, and the processors. We see tonight this measure being slipped through in a machinery Bill and there is not one Government member here to stand up and give some views on it. It is interesting to quote from the Council's response:

The Government has ignored the reality of the situation facing the industry and more importantly has rejected an important element of the sectoral plan for the industry's development even though this plan was prepared through long consultation by growers, processors and trade unions with the Ministers and their Departments.
Furthermore, the Council believes this will discriminate against the industry. It went on to say:
Growers are devastated by the Government's decision and no doubt many will seek to redress what they see as a breach of faith by this Government through other means.

They now have the chance, if they are really serious about what they say-and I am sure they are-to galvanise support against this Government and let their feelings be heard on 11 July because, if there ever was an example of a government trying to slip something through, we have it here tonight. Members of the Government have turned their backs completely on an industry that over a 12-month period put to government a position which the two Ministers responsible accepted and took to Cabinet and which has now been rejected. I should like to hear the Minister in his summing up give some reasons why this position has been taken. The last sentence sums up the Council's sentiments. It would be interesting to go into some of those marginal rural seats where the Labor Party is hoping to win and try to explain this one away. The Council says:
. . . it is apparent that this Government is hell bent on constricting industry development-not enhancing it as it so frequently professes.

So the Government, I believe, stands condemned. One issue that has been raised, and I raised it at the time the decision was taken, is the question of dumping. The Tasmanian vegetable growers and producers will come under greater pressure to survive as a result of the recent report and also, of course, of this Bill to reduce the levels of tariffs. If dumping does occur, the consequent loss of markets and income for Tasmanian vegetable growers and producers may place some jobs in jeopardy. That is undoubted. Staggered reduction in high tariff levels must be accepted-no one would disagree with that-for the long term benefits of growers, producers and consumers, but such acceptance has to be dependent upon the implementation of effective safeguards against dumping on Australian markets of overseas products. The Federal Government proposes-I believe it is somewhere in the Minister's statement-an anti-dumping authority aimed at ensuring fair competition with imports. That ought to be set up immediately. Of course, now we are in the election environment that will not take place. If the Minister bothers to inquire-perhaps he has already-he will know that there are several dumping actions on foot already. So it is no good the Government making such changes and then neglecting to move quickly to address the problems its decision causes.

Indeed, it was interesting to see the response from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the concerns raised about the possibility of dumping which was published in the Launceston Examiner and, I am sure, in other papers as well. It is a fairly tame response to a very serious issue. I notice that the chairman of the rural task force has come in; I had hoped he would speak, but I see he has missed the opportunity. Senator Button said:
It is unlikely to lead to dumping from overseas producers.

That simply is not so. There are dumping actions on foot now, as the Department advisers could well tell the Minister, and my concern is that if we move these tariffs down in such a way as the Government has announced it will open the gate for further dumping to take place, as took place in the pea situation. At a time when we have growing export opportunities for processed potatoes, I think the Government ought to be doing something more than it is doing at the moment.

The other concern raised is the effect this would have on regional employment and so on. This can be amply understood by reading the remarks made by my colleague the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who pointed out that in his area a new factory is under threat. Honourable members on the other side of the chamber may be able to see this headline which says it all: `$15 million plan at risk'-because of this decision. Fifteen million dollars for building a new processing plant is not something to pass off and not worry about. It is of extreme concern. I wonder how much thought was given to the repercussions of taking this particular stance when the decision was made. Tasmanians are going to suffer. Mr Clements, the man in charge of McCain Foods (Australia) Pty Ltd, one of the biggest food processing operations in this country-who originally joined AVIC and who was very enthusiastic about what could be achieved by this consultation process-was certainly very disturbed and poured a lot of cold water on the possibility of the expansion going ahead. Tasmanians still do not know what is going to happen.

In my area of Bass in the north-east of Tasmania, where there is a processing plant and many growers, concern has been expressed for a long period. In November 1986, letters expressing concern were sent to the then Senator Don Grimes, who was based in Launceston. There was a letter from the North Eastern Chamber of Commerce. Although it is not a body prone to react-it has made a sensible contribution to the problems of the regional economy over a long period-it said:

Surely in this time of economic hardship this would be one area worthy of support for the Government's push to buy Australian. With growers already struggling to achieve decent prices on an already difficult market a drop in import tariffs must surely be the final nail in the coffin of the potato industry in Tasmania.

That is the depth of concern that is felt in rural, regional Australia about this decision which is being sneaked through tonight and to which no Government member has spoken, other than the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who spoke in an irrelevant fashion and did not raise any issues relating to the Bill.

The final comment rests with the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Evers, a man who is well regarded in agricultural circles for his expertise. He is only a recent addition to the Tasmanian Parliament and he is already a Minister. He has made his presence felt and has been involved in agriculture for a long time. He was formerly a diplomat and understands quite well the dangers of dumping.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is he?

—Mr Nick Evers. He said that the Tasmanian Government had made strong representations to the IAC, both in the original statement and at the subsequent hearing, for the retention of a 20 per cent tariff on frozen potato products. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, there was considerable new investment in processing facilities elsewhere in Australia which will considerably increase competition on the domestic market. The Federal Government's decision places the viability of this investment at risk.

That is the key-the viability of investment is at risk. We now know that investment is declining. More green fields investment, as it were, is needed and new plant needs to be set up. A $15m operation is now hanging in the balance in Tasmania because of this decision.

I see that I am getting the wind-up, but in any event the Minister understands what I am saying. I hope that in summing up he will answer some of the concerns and issues that I have raised. It gave me great pleasure to second the amendment that was moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) from the National Party. There is a united front on this side of the chamber on the issue that the rate be 15 per cent and not 10 per cent as is proposed by this measure. I have seconded the amendment and would like to see it passed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendment proposed by the Opposition. I begin by dealing with the subject of vegetables and then I will go on to petrol prices. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) pointed out in his opening speech for the Opposition that he favoured a rate of 15 per cent rather than the 10 per cent proposed by the Government for processed vegetables. The Industries Assistance Commission recommended a 10 per cent rate for these vegetables. While the Opposition is opposed to a reduction to 10 per cent, it should be recognised that, in some instances, such a frozen corn and dehydrated products, the 10 per cent actually represents an increase. Of course, the increase will have to be deferred until tariff binding negotiations are completed.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Ryan referred particularly to praties, and concern has been expressed by the industry about imports of frozen french fries from Canada. However, these imports were a response to a short term local shortfall in potatoes for processing. A dumping and subsidy inquiry into peas is already under way. If concern is to be expressed within the industry about dumping and other unfair practices, the industry has a responsibility to raise the matter with the Government, and it will be dealt with expeditiously. Overall, the duty reductions are being phased in over a period of up to seven years. I listened attentively to the speeches made by honourable members opposite, and I did not hear much regard being paid to that seven-year phasing in period. The Government is confident that it will give the industry time to adjust to the lower duties. I give an example. Flour, meal and flakes of potato have a 45 per cent general rate of duty on implementation. That declines to 40 per cent at the beginning of 1988, to 35 per cent at the beginning of 1989, to 30 per cent at the beginning of 1990, to 25 per cent at the beginning of 1991, to 20 per cent at the beginning of 1992 and to 15 per cent in 1993. The 10 per cent rate comes in on 1 January 1994.

To hear a little of the horror stories around, one would think it was all happening overnight. However, an industry that cannot gradually adjust over a seven-year period is, I suggest, in very deep trouble. Similarly, dried, dehydrated or evaporated potatoes decline at exactly the same rate: 45 per cent down to 10 per cent in 1994. On the other hand, dried beans of the species phaseolus vulgaris-which I thought was scandalously neglected in the course of the debate-goes from 20 per cent down to 2 per cent. Tomato paste goes from 25 per cent down to 10 per cent. Canned whole potatoes go down from 20 per cent to 10 per cent.

It should be noted that only potatoes and tomatoes are protected by relatively high tariff rates. Most other vegetable products are assisted at a rate that is closer to 15 per cent. Therefore, to provide a uniform rate of assistance of 15 per cent would not, in the Government's view, place the appropriate amount of pressure on most of the local industry to restructure and to improve its competitive position. That, after all, is the intention.

We have heard some speeches in defence of the industry, and they have not been confined to the Opposition side. The Customs Tariff Validation Bill and the Excise Tariff Validation Bill are part of a series of measures to rationalise tariff levels right across the board. From a national perspective, the rationalisation and uniformity make a great deal of sense, but it must be recognised that sometimes a decision may be misunderstood and may generate unnecessary fears in particular regions. On the Government side, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) has been a tireless advocate for the potato and vegetable processing industry, which is significant in his electorate. He has been active in the Caucus, Caucus committees, lobbying Ministers and expressing concern about the possible adverse effects on the potato industry. He is an effective spokesman for the growers and processors in Ballarat, including employees of McCain Foods (Australia) Pty Ltd.

The Government recognises the need for a close scrutiny of the impact of changes to ensure that there is no detriment to the industry. I draw attention to the contents of a letter that Senator Button sent to the Ballarat Courier on this issue. He says:

The potato sector has proved itself to be competitive and efficient and the Government was most conscious of providing the vegetable industry with an atmosphere of general confidence so as to enable it to continue to make judgments for the future which will ultimately lead to increased exports.

Further it will be of interest that the tariff changes referred to were only one of a number of changes emanating from the decision. As part of the package, a number of tariffs were also increased. Uniformity will eliminate the considerable disparities between tariffs applying to similar goods.

What is the view the industry takes of itself? In response to the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), whose speech could fairly be described as `potatocentric' in nature, I add that the IAC considered reduction in tariff from 50 per cent for dehydrated potatoes and 20 per cent for frozen potatoes to 10 per cent would be unlikely to cause significant adjustment problems. Imports are generally not significant and the industry certainly has not been affected in the past by world prices. Recently, $50m in new investment in processing plant for potatoes was made, after the IAC report came in but before the Government decision. We can interpret that as indicating a high degree of confidence in the industry. The tariff on canned tomatoes is reducing from a range of 17 per cent to 20 per cent to 10 per cent over seven years. The tariff on tomato paste is reducing from 25 per cent to 10 per cent over seven years. The IAC noted that of all sectors tomato growing and processing has been shielded by a high level of assistance from adjustments which have taken place elsewhere, and that such adjustments are desirable to improve efficiency.

With great reluctance I turn away from potatoes and tomatoes, having barely mentioned peas, to the question of petrol pricing. Last Friday's debate on the Excise Tariff Validation Bill and the debate this afternoon and this evening raised the question of differential petrol pricing. The contribution of the Opposition emphasised how prices have increased generally over the years. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) addressed this issue very well. He pointed out the Government's increased use of excise on petroleum to reduce the inherited deficit that we derived from the Liberal era. Let me refer for a moment to the comparative price of fuel in Australia.

It is often forgotten that although there has been a striking fall in the international price of oil per barrel as honourable members were told earlier, few countries have a lower petrol price than our country. I will give the indicative international retail prices of petrol in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. In Italy the price of fuel per litre is the equivalent of $1.48; in France, it is $1.13; in the Netherlands it is $1.11; in Japan it is $1.08; in Austria it is $1.05; in Norway it is $1.04-we must remember that Norway has tremendous access to North Sea oil-in Spain it is 95c; in Sweden it is 95c; in Greece it is 86c; in the United Kingdom-it also has access to North Sea oil and it is an election year too-it is 86c; in the Federal Republic of Germany it is 84c; in New Zealand it is 77c; and in Australia it is 57c. These figures are for March 1987. In Canada it is 46c and in the United States of America it is 40c. When I explain to people in Melbourne that the price of petrol is much dearer in, say, Milan many of them say `I do not often get my petrol in Milan', so there is not much of a basis for comparison.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is more expensive.

—There is a higher unit cost to get there. Occasionally-and I say this in the gentlest possible way to friends from Tasmania-we have to take not just a national position but an international position.
—Why did Bob Hawke tell us it would be cheaper?
—Relatively speaking, if we look at what is happening to the economy, we have done very well in containing the price of petrol.
—Tell that to the motorists.
—Look, it is always--
—Order! The Minister will not answer the interjections. The interjections will cease.

—They are not worth responding to. Australians will continue to benefit under the wise guidance of the Hawke Government from petrol prices which are among the lowest of any comparable industrialised nation. When honourable members talk to their constituents do they ever point out to them where Australia ranks internationally? I suggest that when they talk to them they simply talk in terms of what petrol prices were X years ago without recognising the extraordinary change in world fuel prices over the last few years which reflect--
—What about comparative interest rates?
—The honourable member for Gippsland cannot hide behind Hansard. I can still see him.

—This reflects the concern of this Government to ensure that we maintain some sort of balance. One of the important factors is the fear that if the bottom falls through the petrol market Australia will have a vast increase in the rate of usage. No doubt there is an element of trying to restrain demand. If we have to rely on our own resources at a time when very little exploration is going on, the long term future for self-sufficiency is threatened. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate. It is with profound regret that we will be opposing the amendment.
