QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the National Drug Offensive stated that caffeine is a drug of dependence.
(2) Is it necessary to advise the public, and especially parents, of the problems associated with caffeine.
(3) What (a) foods and (b) drinks contain caffeine.
(4) Is there a maximum limit for the amount of caffeine permitted in foods and drinks sold to the public including children.

(5) Did the Food Science and Technology Sub-Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) recommend in 1982 that the permitted level of caffeine in soft drinks be reduced from 145mg per litre to 75mg per litre and has this expert group repeated this recommendation on a number of occasions since.
(6) Has the Food Standards Committee (FSC) of the NHMRC rejected this recommendation on each occasion.
(7) What are the reasons given by the Committee for rejecting the persistent recommendation of the sub-committee.

(8) Did the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) write to him in December 1985 asking that urgent action be taken to prohibit the addition of caffeine to foods, especially those foods directed toward young children.
(9) Did AFCO also ask that products, such as chocolate, which contain caffeine as a natural ingredient, be labelled with the approximate caffeine content.
(10) Have Australian chocolate manufacturers advised that their chocolate contains 20mg of caffeine in each 300 gram bar and is this the same as about 670mg of caffeine per kilogram.
(11) Does the caffeine content of chocolate overseas normally range from about 50 to 550 mg per kilogram.
(12) Does Australian chocolate appear to have the highest caffeine content of any chocolate in the world.
(13) Did AFCO submit a paper in February 1986 to the FSC setting out its position on caffeine.
(14) Was this paper distributed with the working papers for the March and July meetings of the FSC; if not, why not.

(15) If the submissions of AFCO, and possibly others, are not distributed with the Committee working papers, how can the NHMRC take full account of all views when making recommendations on important matters like food irradiation and caffeine.

(16) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Adelaide News of 2 December 1985, discussing caffeine in soft drinks, where a spokesman for the NHMRC said that caffeine was permitted in both soft drinks and confectionery, that requests for a reduction in the caffeine content had been under discussion for some time, but soft drink companies had said they could not reduce it.
(17) Is he (a) aware of and (b) satisfied with, the handling and progress of the inquiry or study by the FSC into caffeine.

(18) Does the statement of the NHMRC spokesperson referred to in part (16) demonstrate that it is the food and soft drink manufacturers who set the standards for caffeine in food and soft drinks in Australia.
(19) Are the high levels of caffeine in Australian food and soft drink in the best interests of Australian children.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The National Campaign Against Drug Abuse issued a media release on 14 May 1986 describing caffeine as ``probably the world's most popular drug'' and advising that there was ``no doubt that a certain degree of dependence developed towards beverages containing caffeine''.

(2) Yes. As with any pharmacologically active substance it is desirable to avoid excessive caffeine intake. Hence the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse made the media release referred to in (1) and has included a caffeine ``fact sheet'' in the drug information kits available from the National Drug Information Line.

(3) (a) and (b) I am advised that caffeine occurs naturally in minute quantities in more than 60 plant species. In practical terms, it occurs naturally in coffee, tea, cocoa and chocolate, and cola nut extract containing products. As a food additive its use is restricted to cola type soft drinks.
(4) Food regulations control the use of caffeine as a food additive. Cola soft drinks may contain not more than 145 mg/kg of caffeine.

(5) Yes. The Food Science and Technology Subcommittee (FST) of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) did recommend in September 1982 that the permitted level of caffeine in soft drinks be reduced from 145 mg per litre to 75 mg per litre. It repeated this recommendation in February 1986.

(6) No. I am advised that following the FST's first recommendation the Food Standards Committee (FSC) decided to defer action until it had advised the industry of its intention to support the reduction recommended by the FST and obtained information on whether the proposed reduction would cause significant changes to current products.

The FSC subsequently received submissions from the industry which it passed to the FST for further consideration. After further examination of the issue the FST reported in February 1986 that it considered its earlier recommendation still to the be valid.

The FSC reported on the issue at its July 1986 meeting to the effect that it did not endorse the FST's proposed reduction. It did agree to an associated FST recommendation that the presence of caffeine in cola type drinks should be required to be declared in the ingredient list. The FSC also agreed that discussions with the industry should continue and that the subject warranted a watching brief by both committees.
(7) I am advised that the FSC did not endorse the FST's recommendation because:
Australia's maximum permitted level of caffeine in cola type soft drinks (145 mg/kg) is below that of most countries;
cola type beverages contributed only 4% of the total caffeine intake. The FSC questioned whether a 50% reduction of the caffeine content of these soft drinks would be significant;
the vast majority of the FSC agreed that the supporting evidence forwarded by the FST was not persuasive; and

generally cola soft drink manufacturers currently identify caffeine in the statement of ingredients. As noted in (6) above, the FSC agreed that this practice should be maintained and endorsed the FST recommendation that it be a requirement.
(8) Yes.
(9) Yes.

(11) and (12) No. I am advised that the international data available to the NHMRC suggest that the average figures for caffeine in chocolate range from approximately 210 mg/kg-2115 mg/kg depending on the type of chocolate with the average for ``chocolate bar'' being 670 mg/kg.
(14) and (15) I am advised that members of the FSC were provided with AFCO's submission at the March 1986 meeting of that Committee. The issue was further considered by the Committee in July 1986.
(16) My attention has been drawn to a copy of a newspaper article of 2 December 1985 to this effect.

(17) (a) and (b) I am aware of differences of views on the issues involved. Various aspects of the caffeine issue are still being considered by the food committees and the Child Health Committee of the NHMRC. I have requested from NHMRC early clarification on the issue of caffeine in food and drink.
(19) See answers to (1) and (2) above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister provide details on discrepancies on school retention and participation rates within each of the government and non-government schools sectors shown in Statistical Monograph No. 3 of her Department.

(2) Can the Minister provide information in relation to the socio-economic mix of those schools with the highest and lowest participation rates if there is a large discrepancy in the participation rates of individual schools in the government school sector.

(3) How are resources being allocated to redress the apparent imbalance in participation rates in (a) the government and non-government schools sectors and (b) those schools within the government sector which are significantly below acceptable levels of participation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Differences between school participation rates within each of the government and non-government sectors shown in Statistical Monograph No. 3, reflect the different proportion of young people in each age group that attend the different categories of schools.

The apparent retention rates represent the number of students who proceed through to Years 10, 11 and 12 expressed as a percentage of the corresponding group who were enrolled in the first year of secondary education. It therefore represents a broad measure of the tendencies of students to remain at school from the first to each of the last three secondary years.

They can be used to show changes in retention within each sector over a number of years. Thus, the apparent retention rate to year 12 in government schools increased from 29.6 per cent in 1982 to 39.9 per cent in 1985.

Apparent retention rates cannot be used to compare the relative performance of systems. For example, there is a net transfer of students from government to non-government schools especially between years 10 and 11. This tends to inflate the non-government school retention rate, and reduce the government school rates. Moreover, the major variations arise because of the background of students who attend different schools. It is not possible to draw conclusions from these figures about the likelihood of persons of equal ability proceeding through to year 12 in either government or non-government schools.

(2) The retention and participation rates published in Statistical Monograph No. 3 have been derived from data published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). It is not possible to obtain information on a school by school basis as data is provided to the ABS by systems in an aggregated format only.

Other published data are available which provide information related to this question. The most recent is ACER Research Monograph No. 30, Participation in Education. I have arranged for a copy of this report to be placed in the Parliamentary Library.

(3) The major program which the government has used to encourage increased participation to the end of secondary schooling or its equivalent is the Participation and Equity Program (PEP). In the allocation of resources within the government school sector under PEP, priority is given to a limited number of secondary schools, know as target schools, which have low participation rates overall or serve significant numbers of students from groups with traditionally low participation. As near as possible to 40 per cent of government schools are targeted in each State and Territory, using criteria which take account of the social, economic and cultural background of students and the level of participation in upper secondary education. At least 55 per cent of the State PEP allocation for government schools is directed to these target schools.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did Australia Post destroy 40 million commemorative stamps with a face value of over $14m after Australia's failure to retain the America's Cup.
(2) What was the cost to Australia Post of destroying the stamps.
(3) Why did Australia Post produce the commemorative stamps before the America's Cup took place.
(4) Can Australia Post assure the public that the cost of this exercise will not be passed on to the users of Australia Post services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, from information provided by Australia Post, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In anticipation of Australia retaining the America's Cup in 1987, Australia Post arranged for the production, in November 1986, of some 35 million stamps (about a two week supply) depicting a win. The stamps were not `new' but previously issued America's Cup stamps, showing the Cup held aloft, overprinted with a victory sign. These were subsequently destroyed because it would have been inappropriate to issue them after Australia lost the Cup.
(2) Production costs were initially estimated at less than $100,000. The total cost of producing, overprinting, packaging and ultimately destroying the stamps was $120,000.

(3) The stamps were printed to meet the anticipated large public demand in the event that Australia won the Cup. The potential philatelic revenue was very significant. (Australia Post was not prepared for the 1983 win and, when it issued a commemorative envelope some 6 weeks later, over 1 million envelopes were sold.)
(4) Because the loss incurred was minimal considering Australia Post is a $1.3 billion enterprise, postal users will not be faced with increased charges.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Soviet and American Weapons Procurement between 1977 and 1986

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 April 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say how many (a) ICBMs, (b) SLBMs, (c) Surface to air missiles, (d) tanks, (e) submarines and (f) artillery pieces were constructed by the (i) Soviet Union and (ii) US between 1977 and 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The USSR does not make this sort of information available. However the 1987 edition of Soviet Military Power, published by the U.S. Department of Defence, contains a table at page 121 comparing the levels of U.S. and Soviet weapon systems procurement over the period 1977-1986.

According to that table, between 1977 and 1986 the Soviet Union constructed 3,000 ICBMs and SLBMS; 140,000 surface-air-missiles; 24,400 tanks, 90 submarines and 28,200 artillery pieces. Comparable figures for the United States are given as: 850 ICBMs and SLBMs; 16,200 surface-to-air missiles; 7,100 tanks; 43 submarines and 2,750 artillery pieces.
The Government has no reason to dispute these figures.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tourism to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether (a) the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is encouraging Australian tourists to visit North Korea and (b) North Korea has informed Australian travel agents that it will not accept tourists who are Jews.
(2) Has he made any representations to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea protesting at discrimination against Australian citizens who are Jewish; if so, what has been the response.
(3) If he has not made any representations on this matter, will he do so now.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes; (b) My Department has contacted two travel agencies involved in tourism to the DPRK. Neither agency was aware of a DPRK ban on travel by Australian Jews. The DPRK Government informed one agency that it would not accept tourists from Australia who were citizens of countries with which the DPRK did not have diplomatic relations, such as the United States, Japan, Israel, South Africa and Taiwan.
(3) No. Australia's relations with the DPRK have been interrupted since 1975. The Australian Government cannot make representations to a government with which its relations are interrupted.
